chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of cirrhosis
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of a person diagnosed with cirrhosis, including referral, self-care advice, and monitoring.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with cirrhosis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For all people diagnosed with cirrhosis on transient elastography, refer to a specialist in hepatology. 
    • Following referral and specialist assessment, it may be considered appropriate for a person to be managed in primary care, or using a shared-care model.
  • For people who develop decompensated liver disease, refer immediately to a hepatologist or to a gastroenterologist with an interest in hepatology. 
    • Symptoms of decompensated liver disease include (but are not limited to) ascites, encephalopathy and gastrointestinal haemorrhage. For more information see the section on complications.
  • For people who misuse alcohol, consider referral to specialist alcohol services. For more information, see the CKS topic on Alcohol - problem drinking. 
  • For people with end-stage liver disease requiring symptom control or palliative care, refer to the local palliative care team, especially if the likely prognosis is less than 12 months.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Referral of a person diagnosed with cirrhosis
  • The recommendation to refer a person with cirrhosis to a specialist in hepatology is based on the expert opinion of the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline development group [NICE, 2016] and is reiterated by the Royal College of General Practitioners' discussion of the implementation of the NICE guideline [RCGP, 2017]. 
  • Specialist management of cirrhosis may include some of the following interventions [British Liver Trust and RCGP, 2017; RCGP, 2017]: 
    • Detailed assessment of people with compensated cirrhosis to detect people at high risk of serious complications using a score such as the Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) [NICE, 2016]. 
    • Referral of people who have, or are at high risk of, complications of cirrhosis to a specialist hepatology centre [NICE, 2016].
    • Surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma (using 6-monthly ultrasound scans and, in some cases, serum alpha-fetoprotein measurement) [NICE, 2016].
    • Endoscopy to identify oesophageal varices and treatments such as banding to prevent bleeding in people with medium to large oesophageal varices [Tripathi et al, 2015; NICE, 2016].  
Referral of people who develop decompensated liver disease
  • This recommendation is extrapolated from the expert opinion of the NICE GDG in the guideline Hepatitis B (chronic): diagnosis and management [NICE, 2013]. As decompensated liver disease can potentially affect anyone with cirrhosis, CKS is of the opinion that this is a reasonable recommendation because the management of a person with decompensated cirrhosis, irrespective of cause, is beyond the scope of primary care. Specialist management options for the complications of cirrhosis may include:  
    • For upper gastrointestinal bleeding — resuscitation measures such as intravenous volume support and blood transfusion; infusion of vasoactive drugs; prophylactic intravenous antibiotics; balloon tamponade (temporary measure); and endoscopic variceal ligation or glue injection [World Gastroenterology Organisation, 2014; Muir, 2015; NICE, 2016; National Guideline Centre, 2016; Garcia-Tsao et al, 2017]. 
    • For ascites — Diuretics, paracentesis, and prophylactic oral antibiotics (ciprofloxacin or norfloxacin) [European Association for the Study of the Liver, 2010; Runyon, 2012; NICE, 2016]. Placement of a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) to reduce portal pressure in people with refractory ascites, and referral for transplant may also be considered [Muir, 2015; NICE, 2016; Garcia-Tsao et al, 2017]. 
    • For hepatic encephalopathy — non-absorbable disaccharides (usually lactulose) to reduce the pH of the colon and promote excretion of ammonia and its use in the metabolism of gut bacteria, with the aim of 2–3 soft bowel motions per day [Ellul et al, 2015; Shawcross et al, 2016]; antibiotics to reduce enteric bacterial production of ammonia and endotoxins (for example rifaximin) [Vilstrup et al, 2014; Muir, 2015; Shawcross et al, 2016].
    • Dietician input, for an assessment of nutritional status [Vilstrup et al, 2014]. Dietary recommendations depend on the individual and their complications, but may include a no-added salt diet, advice on protein intake, eating small meals through the day (to minimise the effect of protein malnutrition on loss of skeletal muscle mass), avoidance of fasting, and a late-night snack of complex carbohydrates [European Association for the Study of the Liver, 2010; Vilstrup et al, 2014; Ellul et al, 2015].     
Referral of people who misuse alcohol
  • CKS has made this pragmatic recommendation based on what it considers to be good clinical practice. This takes into account advice from the Royal College of General Practitioners and British Liver Trust that GPs have an opportunity to offer support to reduce alcohol consumption in people with cirrhosis if it is being misused [British Liver Trust and RCGP, 2017].  
  • Expert opinion in a review article also notes the improved quality of care with the input of a multidisciplinary alcohol care team, and associated reduction in the risk of acute hospital admission [Tsochatzis et al, 2014]. 
Referral of people with end-stage liver disease to palliative care
  • This recommendation is extrapolated from information published by the Royal College of General Practitioners and the British Liver Trust that discusses the prescribing challenges in a palliative setting for a person with liver failure, and the need for additional support for a person or their relatives if alcohol misuse has contributed to their illness [British Liver Trust and RCGP, 2017]. 
  • Expert opinion in a review article suggests contacting the community palliative care team and considering placing the person on an end of life registry if they are unlikely to survive 12 months. This can help address symptom management to maintain comfort and provide additional support to them and their family at home in the event of complications of end-stage disease (for example variceal bleeding, worsening hepatic encephalopathy, and sepsis) [Ellul et al, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with cirrhosis in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Offer the person advice on:
    • Having cirrhosis.
      • This is explained in the British Liver Trust publication Cirrhosis of the liver and in the NHS information on Cirrhosis.
    • Healthy eating and diet — individualised dietary advice should ideally be provided by a dietician, particularly for people with decompensated cirrhosis. 
      • General information on diet for people with cirrhosis is available from the British Liver Trust in the publication Diet and liver disease. 
    • Alcohol consumption and smoking.
      • The British Liver Trust provides written information and advice on alcohol use in the publications Alcohol and liver disease and Diet and liver disease.
      • For more information on alcohol misuse and helping a person quit smoking, see the CKS topics on Alcohol - problem drinking and Smoking cessation.
    • Driving — give advice on driving relevant to the underlying cause of cirrhosis and the level and nature of complications. For more information, see the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) publication Assessing fitness to drive - a guide for medical professionals. 
    • Using medications safely — seek medical advice before taking any over-the-counter drugs or herbal remedies. 
  • When reviewing a person with cirrhosis in primary care:
    • Review medications and note whether any changes to drugs or dosage are required in relation to liver function. Seek specialist advice if in doubt. 
      • For more information on prescribing for people with liver impairment see the British National Formulary (BNF) or the Summary of Product Characteristics (SmPC) available from the electronic Medicines Compendium (eMC).
    • Ensure the underlying liver disease is being treated (if possible) and they are receiving appropriate specialist follow up and screening for complications of cirrhosis. This will usually be overseen by secondary care, but may be arranged by primary care as part of a shared care model in some cases.
    • Be alert to features of potential complications of cirrhosis to enable timely detection and referral.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Offering advice
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article. This emphasises the importance of lifestyle advice in the management of cirrhosis on the basis that although it is difficult to quantify benefit, it is not costly and is easy to provide, with minimal risk of adverse effects [Tsochatzis et al, 2014]. 
Explanation of the diagnosis
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Advice on healthy eating and diet
  • This recommendation reflects expert advice in patient information from the British Liver Trust [British Liver Trust, 2016]. This suggests individualised dietary advice from a dietician for people with decompensated cirrhosis, and CKS has also extrapolated from clinical practice guidelines on the management of ascites and hepatic encephalopathy [European Association for the Study of the Liver, 2010; Vilstrup et al, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles [Ellul et al, 2015; Ge and Runyon, 2016].
Advice on alcohol abstinence and smoking
  • A clinical practice guideline from the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases and expert opinion in a review article note that, in people with cirrhosis regardless of cause, alcohol use is of prognostic relevance as it is likely to increase portocollateral blood flow and raise the risk of variceal bleeding, therefore people with cirrhosis should be advised to abstain from alcohol [Tsochatzis et al, 2014; Garcia-Tsao et al, 2017].
  • The recommendation to advise a person with cirrhosis to stop smoking is based on expert opinion in a review article. Apart from the general health benefits, in a person with cirrhosis, smoking cessation is also advised to prevent progression of liver disease, facilitate eligibility for liver transplantation if this is necessary, and improve outcomes post-transplant [Tsochatzis et al, 2014].  
Advice on driving
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and is based on the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency document Assessing fitness to drive - a guide for medical professionals [DVLA, 2018] and is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article. This cites evidence that even if people have mild hepatic encephalopathy they are more likely to be involved in a road traffic accident [Ellul et al, 2015].  
Advice on using medications safely and medication review
  • CKS advises giving advice on safe use of medications and reviewing a person's drugs based on extrapolation from Evidence-based recommendations to improve the safe use of drugs in patients with liver cirrhosis [Weersink et al, 2018].
  • Experts acknowledge that, in people with cirrhosis, there can be a major effect on pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics and suggest that choosing appropriate drugs is very important and the risks of medications should be weighed against the benefits. For example, analgesics should be carefully chosen, taking into account the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, hepatic encephalopathy with opiates, and the effects of paracetamol on the liver [Ge and Runyon, 2016]. This is supported by a review article, in which experts advise prescribers to consider drug interactions and the possible need for lower doses when a person has cirrhosis [Tsochatzis et al, 2014].
Ensuring follow-up and monitoring
  • CKS advises treatment where possible for the underlying liver condition in line with expert opinion that this may influence disease progression [Tsochatzis et al, 2014]. A review article on the identification and monitoring of cirrhosis recognises that secondary care is responsible for screening and surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma and varices, but advocates that GPs should confirm arrangements are in place for the person with cirrhosis to receive appropriate investigations [Keane et al, 2016]. This is supported in principle by expert opinion that the management of patients with cirrhosis should aim for a multidisciplinary, unified approach between primary and secondary care [Muir, 2015]. 
Awareness of potential complications
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article which discusses the important role primary healthcare practitioners play in the early recognition of potential diagnoses and collaborating with specialists to manage and prevent complications arising as a result of cirrhosis [Muir, 2015].  
  • A European consensus statement noted that, in contrast to the emergency presentation to a specialist which often occurs with decompensation events such as variceal bleeding or ascites, people with hepatic encephalopathy may present to their primary care practitioner with cognitive dysfunction and there should be a low threshold for suspecting the potential diagnosis, and timely assessment and referral to facilitate early management [Shawcross et al, 2016].
